awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Development of New Ligands and Reactions in Catalysis
Olaf Wiest and Paul Helquist
University of Notre Dame 

Non-technical Abstract:
This project will support research visits of 16 and 10 weeks, respectively, of three graduate and two undergraduate students from the University of Notre Dame to perform research in four of Germany's leading research groups at the University of Heidelberg in the area of catalysis. Catalysis represents the most important general technology in industrial chemistry. More than 80 percent of all chemical products, from pharmaceuticals to high-performance materials, result from use of catalysts at least once during their synthesis. Thus, the development of new and improved catalysts is a central topic in chemistry with huge environmental and economic benefits. Given Heidelberg's prominence in the field of catalysis (as evidenced by the work of several of the 18 winners of the Chemistry Nobel Prize affiliated with the University of Heidelberg) and the structured, long-term character of the proposed program, the students will not only gain the skills and experience but also have networking opportunities to thrive in today's international, interconnected world of science and business.

Technical Abstract:
The research is divided into four broad areas covering a range of modern topics in catalysis that are common areas of strength researchers at the Universities of Notre Dame and Heidelberg: (i) Ligands, methodology and mechanisms in gold catalysis (Hashmi), (ii) chiral catalysts with polydentate stereodirecting ligands (Gade), (iii) Oxidation catalysis with high-valent transition metal complexes (Comba) and (iv) Single-Molecule Catalysis (Herten). The individual projects cover organic, metalorganic and physical chemistry aspects of catalysis are designed to interface the research interests of faculty members at the two participating universities. They incorporate a large number of new concepts such as a) new privileged ligand scaffolds that allow the precise positioning of directing groups, e.g. for nitrogen transfer reactions, b) new types of gold-catalyzed reactions such as photoredox catalysis without a secondary metal, c) novel ligands for the stabilization of biomimetic high-valent metals in catalysis and (d) the study of elementary reaction steps of important catalytic reactions such as metathesis or epoxidation reactions at the single molecule level. Their unifying principle is a rigorous structure- and mechanism-based approach whereby a range of advanced experimental and computational tools are used to generate a hypothesis, which is then tested experimentally in an iterative and accelerated fashion.

por.por_cntn:
This IRES program provided international research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students from the University of Notre Dame at the University of Heidelberg (Germany) in all aspects of catalysis. The students gained experience in advanced experimental and computational methods at one of the world’s top research universities. Several faculty members at Heidelberg have received Nobel Prizes. In addition, the students benefited from exposure to both the academic environment and everyday culture of another country in comparison to the USA.

Between 2018 and 2023 (interrupted due to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 and 2021), four cohorts with a total of four graduate students and fifteen undergraduate students performed research for 10 and 16 weeks, respectively, starting the second week of May of each year. Each cohort included students from underrepresented groups (three Latinas, one African American student) and were evenly matched between male and female students (ten female, nine male students). In addition, eight undergraduate students (five female, three male ) funded by the College of Science participated in the program. The long-term impact and experience for the students was further enhanced by workshop on german language and culture in the spring semester before their stay at the university of Heidelberg.  Two unique aspects of the program are that is a complementary program, funded by the German Academic Exchange Service that brought 17 students from Heidelberg to perform research for seven months starting in august of each year at the University of Notre Dame during the grant period and that both programs are embedded in a university-wide collaboration between the two universities.      

They research mentors at the University of Heidelberg are international leaders in different aspects of catalysis. Prof. S. Hashmi is the pioneer of gold catalysis in organic synthesis, which led to gold compounds becoming very prominent as catalysts, exhibiting reaction properties that complement those of more commonly used metals, including palladium, platinum, rhodium, and iridium. Prof. A. Dreuw, is an expert in the development of new computational methods and the director of the Institute for Scientific Computation. For example, one of the recent IRES students in his group performed computational studies to seek out derivatives of RNA having specific electronic and fluorescence characteristics. These materials are intended for use by other researchers studying the properties of RNA. Applications of forms of RNA have arisen in the public eye recently due to the vaccines that have been successfully introduced for treatment of COVID-19. Prof. Gade is internationally recognized for his work in catalysis as applied to the synthesis of novel materials. Several IRES students worked in his group on the development of efficient, lower-cost and environmentally friendly catalysts for the generation of these materials. Prof, Comba, who retired at the start of 2023, mentored several IRES students working at the interface of catalysis and analytical chemistry, which allowed training of students in new analytical methods that they brought back to Notre Dame.  

In doing this research, the students mastered several advanced research techniques. They also received experience in giving presentations of their results at both universities and in writing scientific reports, several of which have been published in peer-reviewed journals. The students have brought this enhanced level of training back to Notre Dame where they are continuing to do advanced research in the laboratories of faculty members. The overall research experiences of these students have given them strong credentials and motivation to pursue advanced degrees and professional careers among the next generation of scientists.
